DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to investigate the individual and combined effects of dark chocolate/cocoa and almonds on lipids, lipoproteins, antioxidant defense, lipid peroxidation, phenolic acids, inflammatory status, blood pressure and arterial health. It is hypothesized that dark chocolate/cocoa and/or almonds will favorably affect lipids, lipoproteins, antioxidants, inflammatory status, blood pressure and arterial health compared to a healthy American control diet; however, the effects will be greater when dark chocolate/cocoa and almonds are consumed together versus consumption of each food individually.
DOC.brief_title: Effects of Polyphenolic-rich Dark Chocolate/Cocoa and Almonds on Cardiovascular Disease Risk Factors
DOC.criteria: Overweight and obese (BMI ≥25, ≤40 kg/m2) Moderately elevated LDLC between the 2595th percentile from NHANES: 105194 mg/dL for males; 98190 mg/dL for females. Tobacco use Systolic blood pressure ≥159 mm Hg Diastolic blood pressure ≥ 99 mm Hg A history of myocardial infarction, stroke, diabetes mellitus, liver disease, kidney disease, and thyroid disease (unless controlled on meds) Blood pressure or cholesterollowering medication use Refusal to discontinue intake of putative cholesterollowering supplements (e.g. psyllium, fish oil, soy lecithin, niacin, fiber, flax, stanols/sterols) Vegetarianism or dietary practices that are inconsistent with the test diets Nut allergies Refusal to discontinue nutritional supplements, herbs, or vitamins History of inflammatory gastrointestinal disease
